awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Using a Network of Campus Testbeds and Community Engagement to Accelerate the Mutual Creation, Adoption, and Transfer of Urban Innovation in Cities
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal highlights two barriers limiting the ability of technology to improve the quality of life in cities: (1) a mismatch between the needs of communities and of the private and public sectors, and (2) a distrust among community members of companies and city governments promoting technological change. It explores the hypothesis that both challenges can be overcome using a network of campus-based testbeds where city residents, governments, companies, and academics can assess new applications under relatively controlled conditions before dispatching them more broadly. Using five contrasting testbeds in Portland OR, Seattle WA, and Vancouver BC (Portland State University, the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry, Portland International Airport, University of Washington, and University of British Columbia), and focusing on three distinct application areas (accessibility for people with disabilities, integration of building energy efficiency and public health, and protection of the climate-ameliorating capacities of urban trees) this project will compare how stakeholder groups use novel technologies to increase prioritized civic values. The testbed network will create an urban innovation evaluation pipeline consisting of problem identification, digital assessment of current conditions, implementation of campus-based testing, and evaluation and scaling of results to create civic value, all in partnership with five core constituencies: community stakeholder groups, city government, large tech firms, small startups, and universities. The highly interdisciplinary research proposed here builds on a unique set of corporate, academic, municipal, and nonprofit investments and partnerships to help define a more inclusive and responsive ecosystem of urban innovation.

Through close coordination with core urban constituencies, this project will design and deploy novel combinations of technologies across a five-campus network. This project will also use three strands of social science research to examine: (1) how locally tested innovations can increase their impact on larger socio-technical systems through better coordination, (2) how negotiation and compromise can overcome different constituencies’ objections to implementation, and (3) how engaging communities earlier in the evaluation process can address concerns and help resolve the mismatch between community motives and technological outcomes. Recommendations from these studies can increase the chances that technology use leads to more inclusive, productive, and impactful urban problem-solving. Success will be measured by (1) cities more rapidly finding new combinations of digital applications that effectively address community needs; (2) community groups reporting that their city is more responsive to their priorities; and (3) companies creatively and profitably responding to what urban residents want.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past two decades, there has been a great deal of excitement about how digital innovation could keep people in cities safer, healthier, and more prosperous. However, these prospects have been clouded by concerns about privacy, monopolization, gentrification, and effectiveness. The purpose of the research supported by our NSF-funded planning grant has been to show how specific technologies can help make cities more responsive to the needs of their residents, governments, and companies.

We have used a network of five campuses in the major cities of the Pacific Northwest (Portland, Seattle, and Vancouver BC) to evaluate how different technologies from startup companies and major tech firms can address issues of accessibility, climate change, and resilience. This work has been coordinated by the Digital City Testbed Center (DCTC), a "smart city" research program established in 2019 with a $1.5M investment from Portland State University (PSU). DCTC is currently focused on three rapidly growing risks--extreme heat, wildfire smoke, and urban conflagration--especially as they affect vulnerable urban populations.

As an example, Portland has long been known for fresh air, temperate climate, and beautiful mountain vistas. But in the past five years, wildfire smoke has caused the city to repeatedly experience the world's worst air quality, while unusual weather patterns have broken previous temperature records by more than 10 degrees F. Most alarmingly, wildfires have entered the metropolitan area, from the east (in 2017) and the south (in 2020), only avoiding becoming major disasters because of fortuitous, last-minute wind changes. Tree-ring studies have shown that the basins occupied by all three of the Northwest's major cities have been subject to forest-obliterating wildfires every 250-500 years, a threat that remains under-appreciated, even as the region becomes more aware of the risks posed by earthquakes, landslides, and volcanic eruptions.

These ongoing climate-change-driven effects have been particularly dangerous to vulnerable populations--people with disabilities, the elderly, and those lacking adequate shelter or ready access to transportation. As a result, the City of Portland has been sued because of its inability to help people with disabilities get to shelters offering cool and clean air. We seek to develop technology- and policy-based solutions that can protect all city residents from these climate challenges.

During the funding period, we carried out and evaluated a series of deployments of digital technologies on the campuses of PSU and University of British Columbia (UBC). One set compared assistive technologies for visually impaired users (Waymap, Goodmaps, AccessiBuild, and "Smart Paint" from Intelligent Materials), receiving feedback from blind and deaf-blind volunteers that helped the technology startup companies improve their products and services. A second project looked at how Wi-Fi-based occupancy information can be linked to HVAC systems to reduce energy consumption and to target enhanced airflow for COVID dispersal and smoke dilution to those parts of buildings where the most people are. A third deployment used the "Hello Lamp Post" public engagement software program to inform and query the public about how technology can detect air pollution caused by wildfire smoke. In a fourth engagement, we discussed with San Francisco-based startup Salo Sciences how their tree-mapping and fire forecasting tools could be used to evaluate which peri-urban neighborhoods were most at risk from wildfire incursions in metro Portland.

Our planning grant was also used to fund a survey of over 1000 residents of metro Portland about the risks they face concerning heat, smoke, and wildfire, and how much trust they place in government, companies, and university researchers. This was the third such survey funded by the DCTC over the past three years. 

Another set of activities involved meeting with representatives of three neighborhood associations in Portland who were particularly concerned about air quality and discussing affordable, technology-based strategies for reducing the impacts of wildfire smoke on residents' health. To expand our network of potential collaborators, we also took advantage of a series of over 100 webinars on wildfires and urban smoke in the Pacific Northwest, organized by P.I. Fink in 2020 as part of the Cascadia Innovation Corridor economic development initiative.

This grant led to the preparation and submission in June 2022 of a $2M proposal to the National Science Foundation's Smart and Connected Communities program. Although the proposal was not funded, the reviews provided good guidance for a revised submission planned for early 2023.
